I cannot be without thee. Thus then, sirrah:
To bear away suspicion from the thoughts
Of ruder-list'ning servants about house,
I have advised Votarius at fit time
Boldly to force his way into my chamber,
The admittance being denied him, and the passage
Kept strict by thee, my necessary woman.
(La! There I should ha’ missed thy help again!)
At which attempt I’ll take occasion
To dissemble such an anger that the world
Shall ever after swear us to their thoughts
As clear and free from any fleshly knowledge, As nearest kindred are, or ought to be, Or what can more express it, if that failed.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: You know I’m always at your service, madam, But why some privy armour?

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Marry, sweetheart,
The best is yet forgotten; thou shalt hang A weapon in some corner of the chamber, Yonder, or thereâ€”

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Or anywhere. Why, i’faith, madam,
Do you think I’m to learn how to hang a weapon? As much as I’m uncapable of what follows,
I've all your mind without books. Think it done, madam.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Thanks, my good wench; I’ll never call thee worse.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Faith, y’are like to ha‘t again, and you do, madam.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: What, art alone?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Cuds me, what make you here, sir?
You're a bold long-nosed fellow.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: How!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: So my lady says.
Faith, she and I have had a bout for you, sir, But she got nothing by‘t.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: Did I not say still
Thou wouldst be too adventurous!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Ne'er a whit, sir.
I made her glad to seek my friendship first.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: By my faith, that showed well. If you come off
So brave a conqueress, to’t again and spare not, I know not which way you should get more honour.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: She trusts me now to cast a mist, forsooth, Before the servants’ eyes. I must remember
Votarius to come once with privy armour
Into her chamber, when with feigned fury
And rapier drawn, which I must lay a purpose
Ready for her dissemblance, she will seem
T'act wonders for her juggling honesty.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: I wish no riper vengeance! Canst conceive me?
Votarius is my enemy.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: That’s stale news, sir.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: Mark what I say to thee; forget of purpose That privy armour; do not bless his soul With so much warning, nor his hated body
With such sure safety. Here express thy love:
Lay some empoisoned weapon next her hand,
That in that play he may be lost forever.
I‘d have him kept no longer; away with him!
One touch will set him flying! Let him go!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Bribe me but with a kiss, it shall be so.

scene.scenepersonae: (Tyrant, First Nobleman, Memphonius, First Soldier, Second Soldier, Third Soldier, Fourth Soldier)
scene.stagedir: Enter Tyrant, wondrous discontentedly. Nobles afar off.

speech.speaker: 1. NOBLE.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Begone, or never see life more!
I’ll send thee far enough from court.
Memphonius!
Where’s he now?

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: Ever at your highness’ service.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: How ar’st thou be so near, when we have threatened Death to thy fellow! Have we lost our power? Or thou thy fear? Leave us in time of grace; 'Twill be too late anon.

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: I think ‘tis so with thee already

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Dead! And I so healthful! There’s no equality in this. Stay!

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: Sir?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Where is that fellow brought the first report to us?

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: He waits without.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: I charge thee give command
That he be executed speedily,
As thou‘t stand firm thyself.

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: Now by my faith
His tongue has helped his neck to a sweet bargain.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Her own fair hand so cruel! Did she choose Destruction before me? Was I no better?
How much am I exalted to my face,
And where I would be graced, how little worthy!
There’s few kings know how rich they are in goodness,
Or what estate they have in grace and virtue.
There is so much deceit in glozers’ tongues
The truth is taken from us; we know nothing
But what is for their purpose. That’s our stint;
We are allowed no more. O, wretched greatness!
I’ll cause a sessions for my flatterers
And have ‘em all hanged up. 'Tis done too late.
O she’s destroyed, married to death and silence,
Which nothing can divorce, riches nor laws,
Nor all the violence that this fame can raise.
I've lost the comfort of her sight forever.
I cannot call this life that flames within me,
But everlasting torment lighted up
To show my soul her beggary! A new joy
Is come to visit me in spite of death!
It takes me of that sudden, I’m ashamed
Of my provision, but a friend will bear. Within there!

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Sir!

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: The men I wished for, for secrecy and employment. Go, give order that Govianus be released.

speech.speaker: 4. SOLD.
speech.line: Released, sir?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Set free. And then I trust he will fly the kingdom, And never know my purpose. Run, sir!
You!
Bring me the keys of the cathedral straight.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Are you so holy now? Do you curse all day And go to pray at midnight?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Provide you, sirs, close lanthorns and a pickaxe. Away, be speedy!

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Lanthorns and a pickaxe?
Life, does he mean to bury himself alive, too?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Death nor the marble prison my love sleeps in Shall keep her body locked up from mine arms; I must not be so cozened; though her life
Was like a widow’s state, made o'er in policy
To defeat me and my too confident heart. 'Twas a most cruel wisdom to herself, As much to me that loved her. What, returned?

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Here be the keys, my lord.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: I thank thy speed.
Here come the rest full-furnished.
Follow me
And wealth shall follow you.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Wealth! By this light,
We go to rob a church! I hold my life The money will ne’er thrive; that’s a sure saw: "What’s got from grace is ever spent in law."

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: What strange fits grow upon him! Here alate His soul has got a very dreadful leader, What should he make in the cathedral now, The hour so deep in night? All his intents Are contrary to men; in spirit or blood He waxes heavy in his noble mind. His moods are such they cannot bear the weight, Nor will not long, if there be truth in whispers. The honorable father of the state, Noble Helvetius, all the lords agree By some close policy shortly to set free.

scene.scenepersonae: (Tyrant, First Soldier, Second Soldier, Third Soldier, Fourth Soldier)
scene.stagedir: Enter the Tyrant with Soldiers at a farther door, which opened, brings him to the tomb where the Lady lies buried. The tomb is here discovered, richly set forth.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Softly, softly!
Let’s give this place the peace that it requires.
The vaults e’en chide our steps with murmuring sounds, For making bold so late. It must be done.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: I fear nothing but the whorish ghost of a queen I kept once. She swore she would so haunt me I should never pray in quiet for her, and I have kept myself from
church this fifteen year to prevent her.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: The monument woos me! I must run and kiss it. Now trust me if the tears do not e’en stand Upon the marble. What slow springs have I!
'Twas weeping to itself before I came.
How pity strikes e’en through insensible things
And makes them shame our dullness!
Thou house of silence, and the calms of rest
After tempestuous life, I claim of thee
A mistress, one of the most beauteous sleepers
That ever lay so cold, not yet due to thee By natural death, but cruelly forced hither Many a year before the world could spare her. we miss her 'mongst the glories of our court
When they be numbered up. All thy still strength,
Thou grey-eyed monument, shall not keep her from us.
To Second Soldier Strike, villain! Though the echo rail us all Into ridiculous deafness! Pierce the jaws Of this cold ponderous creature.

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Sir!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Why strik’st thou not?

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: I shall not hold the axe fast, I’m afraid, sir.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O shame of men! A soldier and so fearful!

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Tis out of my element to be in a church, sir. Give me the open field and turn me loose, sir.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: True, there thou hast room enough to run away!
Take thou the axe from him.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: I beseech your grace,
Twill come to a worse hand. You'll find us all Of one mind for the church, I can assure you, sir.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Nor thou?

speech.speaker: 3. SOLD.
speech.line: I love not to disquiet ghosts
Of any people living. That’s my humour, sir.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O slaves of one opinion!
Give me‘t from thee,
Thou man made out of fear.

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: By my faith,
I’m glad I’m rid on’t. I that was ne’er before in a cathedral
And have the batt'ring of a lady’s tomb
Lie hard upon my conscience at first coming!
I should get much by that! It shall be a warning to me;
I’ll ne’er come here again.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Striking at the tomb. No? Wilt not yield? Art thou so loath to part from her?

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Life, what means he?
Has he no feeling with him? By this light, if I be not afraid to stay any longer. I’m a stone-cutter! Very few will go nigh to turn me of some religion or other, and so
make me forfeit my lieutenantship.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O, have we got the mastery? Help, you vassals! Freeze you in idleness and can see us sweat?

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: We sweat with fear as much as work can make us.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Remove the stone, that I may see my mistress.
Set to your hands, you villains, and that nimbly, Or the same axe shall make you all fly open!

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: O, good my lord!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: I must not be delayed.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: This is ten thousand times worse than entering
upon a breech. Tis the first stone that ever I took off from any lady; marry, I have brought ‘em many: fair diamonds, sapphires, rubiesâ€”
They lift off the stone

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O blessed object!

I never shall be weary to behold thee; I could eternally stand thus and see thee. Why, ‘tis not possible death should look so fair, Life is not more illustrious when health smiles on’t. She’s only pale, the colour of the court, And most attractive; mistresses most strive for‘t, And their lascivious servants best effect it. Where be these lazy hands again?

speech.speaker: ALL SOLDIERS.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Take up her body.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: How, my lord?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Her body!

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: She’s dead, my lord!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: True; if she were alive
Such slaves as you should not come near to touch her. Do‘t, and with all best reverence. Place her here.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Not only, sir, with reverence, but with fear. You shall have more than your own asking once. I am afraid of nothing but she'll rise At the first jog and save us all a labour.

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Then we were best take her up, and never
touch her!

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Life, how can that be? Does fear make thee mad? I've took up many a woman in my days, But never with less pleasure; I protest.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O, the moon rises! What reflection
Is thrown about this sanctified building,
E’en in a twinkling! How the monuments glister
As if death’s palaces were all massy silver
And scorned the name of marble! Art thou cold?
I have no faith in‘t yet; I believe none.
Madam! 'Tis I, sweet lady. Prithee speak!
'Tis thy love calls on theeâ€”thy king, thy servant. No? Not a word? All prisoners to pale silence? I’ll prove a kiss.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Here’s fine chill venery!
'Twould make a pander’s heels ache; I’ll be sworn
All my teeth chatter in my head to see‘t.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: B‘th' mass, thou'rt cold indeed! Beshrew thee for‘t! Unkind to thine own blood? Hard-hearted lady! What injury hast thou offered to the youth And pleasure of thy days! Refuse the court
And steal to this hard lodging! Was that wisdom?
O, I could chide thee with mine eye brimfull,
And weep out my forgiveness when I ha’ done.
Nothing hurt thee but want of woman’s counsel.
Hads‘t thou but asked th'opinion of most ladies,
Thou'dst never come to this! They would have told thee
How dear a treasure life and youth had been.
'Tis that they fear to lose; the very name
Can make more gaudy tremblers in a minute
Than heaven or sin or hell. Those are last thought on.
And where got’st thou such boldness from the rest

Of all thy timorous sex to do a deed here Upon thyself would plunge the world’s best soldier And make him twice bethink him and again, And yet give over? Since thy life has left me, I’ll clasp the body for the spirit that dwelt in‘t, And love the house still for the mistress’ sake. Thou art mine now, spite of destruction And Govianus, and I will possess thee. I once read of a Herod, whose affection Pursued a virgin’s love as I did thine, Who, for the hate she owed him, killed herself, As thou too rashly didst, without all pity. Yet he preserved her body dead in honey And kept her long after her funeral. But I’ll unlock the treasure-house of art With keys of gold and bestow all on thee. Here, slaves, receive her humbly from our arms. Upon your knees, you villains! All’s too little If you should sweep the pavement with your lips.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: What strange brooms he invents!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: So reverently
Bear her before us gently to our palace. Place you the stone again where first we found it.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt with body. Manet First Soldier.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Life, must this on now to deceive all comers, And cover emptiness? 'Tis for all the world
Like a great city-pie brought to a table
Where there be many hands that lay about;
The lid’s shut close when all the meat’s picked out,
Yet stands to make a show and cozen people.

scene.scenelocation: Within the cathedral, before the Lady’s tomb.
scene.stagedir: Enter Govianus in black, a book in his hand, his Page carrying a torch before him.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Already mine eyes melts. The monument
No sooner stood before it but a tear Ran swiftly from me to express her duty. Temple of honour, I salute thee early,
The time that my griefs rise! Chamber of peace,
Where wounded virtue sleeps locked from the world,
I bring to be acquainted with thy silence
Sorrows that love no noise: they dwell all inward,
Where truth and love in every man should dwell.
Be ready, boy! Give me the strain again.
'Twill show well here, whilst in my grief’s devotion
At every rest mine eye lets fall a bead
To keep the number perfect.

scene.stagedir: Govianus kneels at the tomb, wondrous passionately. His Page sings.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: If ever pity were well-placed On true desert and virtuous honour, It could ne’er be better graced.
Freely then, bestow‘t upon her.
Never lady earned her fame In virtue’s war with greater strife. To preserve her constant name She gave up beauty, youth and life.
There she sleeps
And here he weeps,
The lord unto so rare a wife.
Weep, weep and mourn! Lament, You virgins that pass by her.
For if praise come by death again
I doubt few will lie nigh her.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Thou art an honest boy. Tis done like one That has a feeling of his master’s passions. And the unmatched worth of his dead mistress. Thy better years shall find me good to thee When understanding ripens in thy soul, Which truly makes the man, and not long time. Prithee withdraw a little, and attend me At cloister door.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: It shall be done, my lord.
The Page withdraws

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Eternal maid of honour, whose chaste body Lies here like virtue’s close and hidden seed, To spring forth glorious to eternity At the everlasting harvestâ€”
I am not here.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: What’s that? Who is not here? I’m forced to
question it-
Some idle sounds the beaten vaults send forth.

On a sudden, in a kind of noise like a wind, the doors clattering, the tombstone flies open, and a great light appears in the midst of the tomb; his Lady as went out, standing just before him all in white, stuck with jewels, and a great crucifix on her breast.
Mercy look to me! Faith, I fly to thee!
Keep a strong watch about me! (Now thy friendship!)
O
To have my breast shake and my hair stand stiff.
If this be horror, let it never die!
Come all the pains of hell in that shape to me,
This fever for felicity of man,
Or all the pleasures of ten thousand ages.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: Dear lord, I come to tell you all my wrongs.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Welcome! Who wrongs the spirit of my love? Thou art above the injuries of blood; They cannot reach thee now. What dares offend thee? No life that has the weight of flesh upon’t And treads as I do can now wrong my mistress.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: The peace that death allows me is not mine. The monument is robbed! Behold, I’m gone,
My body taken up!
'Tis gone indeed! What villain dares so fearfully run in debt To black eternity?

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: He that dares do moreâ€”
The Tyrant!

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: All the miseries below Reward his boldness!

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: I am now at court
In his own private chamber. There he woos me And plies his suit to me with as serious pains As if the short flame of mortality Were lighted up again in my cold breast,
Folds me within his arms and often sets
A sinful kiss upon my senseless lip,
Weeps when he sees the paleness of my cheek,
And will send privately for a hand of art
That may dissemble life upon my face
To please his lustful eye.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: O piteous wrongs!
Inhuman injuries without grace or mercy!

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: I leave ‘em to thy thought, dearest of men.
My rest is lost! Thou must restore‘t again.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: O, fly me not so soon!

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: Farewell, true lord.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: I cannot spare thee yet. I’ll make myself
Over to death too, and we'll walk together Like loving spirits: I prithee let’s do so. She’s snatched away by fate and I talk sickly; I must dispatch this business upon earth
Before I take that journey.
I’ll to my brother for his aid or counsel. So wronged! O heav’n, put armour on my spirit! Her body I will place in her first rest Or in th'attempt lock death into my breast.

scene.scenepersonae: (Votarius, Anselmus, Leonella, Bellarius, Anselmus's Wife, Govianus)
scene.stagedir: Enter Votarius with Anselmus, the husband.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: You shall stand here, my lord, unseen and hear all.
Do I deal now like a right friend with you?

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: Like a most faithful.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: You shall have her mind e’en as it comes to me,
Though I undo her by‘t. Your friendship, sir,
Is the sweet mistress that I only serve. I prize the roughness of a man’s embrace Before the soft lips of a hundred ladies.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: And that’s an honest mind of thee.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: Lock yourself, sir,
Into that closet, and be sure none see you!
Trust not a creature. We'll have all run clear, E’en as the heart affords it.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: 'Tis a match, sir.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: Troth, he says true there. 'Tis a match indeed. He does not know the strength of his own words, For if he did there were no mast'ring on him.
H’as cleft the pin in two with a blind man’s eyes. Though I shoot wide, I’ll cozen him of the game.

scene.stagedir: Exit Votarius. Enter Leonella above, in a gallery, with her love Bellarius.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Doest thou see thine enemy walk?

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: I would I did not.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Prithee rest quiet, man; I have fee'd one for himâ€” A trusty catchpole, too, that will be sure on him. Thou know’st this gallery well; ‘tis at thy use now; 'T'as been at mine full often. Thou may’st sit Like a most private gallant in yon corner, See all the play, and ne’er be seen thyself.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: Therefore I chose it.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Thou shalt see my lady
Play her part naturally, more to the life Than she’s aware on.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: There must I be pleased.
Thou'rt one of the actors; thou‘t be missed anon.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Alas, a woman’s action’s always ready. Yet I’ll down, now I think on’t.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: I know not yet where I should plant belief, I am so strangely tossed between two tales, I’m told by my wife’s woman the deed’s done, And in Votarius’ tongue ‘tis yet to come; The castle is but upon yielding yet. 'Tis not delivered up. Well, we shall find The mystery shortly. I will entertain The patience of a prisoner i‘th' meantime.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: Do: ‘tis time, i’faith.

scene.stagedir: Anselmus locks himself in. Enter Anselmus’s Wife with Leonella.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Is all set ready, wench?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Pish, madam, all!

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Tell me not so. She lives not for a lady That has less peace than I.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Nay, good sweet madam,
You would not think how much this passion alters you. It drinks up all the beauty of your cheek;
I promise you, madam, you have lost much blood.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Let it draw death upon me, for till then I shall be mistress of no true content. Who could endure hourly temptation And bear it as I do?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Nay, that’s most certainâ€”
Unless it were myself again: I can do‘t. I suffer the like daily; you should complain, madam.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Which way? Were that wisdom? Prithee, wench, to whom?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: To him that makes all whole againâ€”my lord!
To one that, if he be a kind good husband,
Will let you bear no more than you are able.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Thou know’st not what thou speak’st. Why, my lord’s he That gives him the house-freedom, all his boldness, Keeps him a purpose here to war with me.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Now I hold wiser of my lord than so.
He knows the world; he would not be so idle.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: I speak sad truth to thee. I am not private
In mine own chamber, such his impudence is. Nay, my repenting-time is scarce blessed from him; He will offend my prayers.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Out upon him
I believe, madam, he’s of no religion.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: He serves my lord, and that’s enough for him, And he preys upon poor ladies like myself. There’s all the gentleman’s devotion!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Marry, the devil of hell give him his blessing!

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Pray watch the door, and suffer none to trouble us, Unless it be my lord.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: 'Twas finely spoke, that!
My lord indeed is the most trouble to her. Now I must show a piece of service here.
How do I spend my days! Life, shall I never
Get higher than a lady’s doorkeeper? I must be married as my lady is, first, And then my maid may do as much for me.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: O miserable time! Except my lord Do wake in honourable pity to me, And rid this vicious gamester from his house, Whom I have checked so often, here I vow I’ll imitate my noble sister’s fate, Late mistress to the worthy Govianus, And cast away my life as she did hers.

scene.stagedir: Enter Votarius to the door within.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Back! Y'are too forward, sir! There’s no coming
for you.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: How, Mistress Len, my lady’s smock-woman! Am I no farther in your duty yet?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Duty! Look for‘t of them you keep under, sir.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: You'll let me in?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Who would you speak withal?

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: With the best lady you make curtsy to.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: She will not speak with you.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: Have you her mind?
I scorn to take her answer of her broker.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Madam!

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: What’s there? How now, sir! What’s your business?
We see your boldness plain.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: I came to see you, madam.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Farewell, then! Though ‘twas impudence too much When I was private.

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: Madam!

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Life, he was bom
To beggar all my patience!

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: I’m bold
Still to prefer my love. Your woman hears me not.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Where’s modesty and honour? Have I not thrice
Answered thy lust?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: By'r lady, I think oftener.

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: And ar’st thou yet look with temptation on us?
Since nothing will prevail, come death! Come vengeance! I will forget the weakness of my kind And force thee from my chamber.
She thrusts at Votarius with the sword

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: How now, lady!
'Uds life! You prick me, madam!

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Prithee, peace!
I will not hurt thee.
Aloud
Will you yet be gone, sir?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: He’s upon going, I think

speech.speaker: VOT.
speech.line: Madam! Heart, you deal false with me. O, I feel it!
Y'are a most treacherous lady! This thy glory?
My breast is all afire! O!â€”
Votarius dies

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: Ha! I believe her constancy too late,
Confirmed e’en in the blood of my best friend.
speech.stagedir: He seizes the sword from his Wife.
speech.line: Take thou my vengeance, thou bold, perjurious strumpet, That dust accuse thy virtuous lady falsely.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: O deadly poison after a sweet banquet! What make I here? I had forgot my part! I am an actor too, and ne’er thought on’t. The blackness of this season cannot miss me. To Anselmus. Sirrah! You, lord!
Bellarius draws a sword

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: Is he there? Welcome, ruin!

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: There is a life due to me in that bosom For this poor gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: And art thou then receiver?
I’ll pay thee largely, slave, for thy last ’scape.
They make a dangerous pass at one another. The wife purposely runs between, and is killed
by them both

speech.speaker: WIFE.
speech.line: I come, Votarius!
Dies

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: Hold, if manhood guide thee!
O what has fury done?

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: What has it done now?
Why, killed an honourable whore, that’s all.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: Villain! I’ll seal that lie upon thy heart.
A constant lady!
He kneels at his Wife’s side

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: Go to the devil, as could be!
Heart! Must I prick you forward? Either up, Or, sir, I’ll take my chance. Thou couldst kill her Without repenting that deserved more pity!
And spend’st thy time and tears upon a queenâ€”

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: Slave!

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: That was deceived once in her own deceit,
They fight, and each is mortally stabbed As I am now. The poison I prepared Upon that weapon for mine enemy’s bosom
Is bold to take acquaintance of my blood too,
And serves us both to make up death withal.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: I ask no more of destiny but to fall
Close by the chaste side of my virtuous mistress. If all the treasure of my weeping strength
Be left so wealthy but to purchase that,
I have the dear wish of a great man’s spirit. Yet favor me, O yet.
I thank thee, fate; I expire cheerfully, and give death a smile.

scene.stagedir: Anselmus swoons and appears to die.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: O rage! I pity now mine enemy’s flesh.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Where should he be?

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: My lady, sir, will tell you.
She’s in her chamber here.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV.
speech.line: Seeing bodies. O my lord!

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Peace!â€”My honorable brotherâ€”madamâ€”all! So many dreadful deeds, and not one tongue Left to proclaim ‘em)

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: Yes, here! If a voice
Some minute long may satisfy your ear,
I've that time allowed it.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Tis enough.
Bestow it quickly, ere death snatch it from thee.

speech.speaker: BEL.
speech.line: That lord your brother made his friend Votarius To tempt his lady. She was won to lust,
The act revealed here by her serving-woman.
But that wise, close adulteress, stored with art
To prey upon the weakness of that lord,
Dissembled a great rage upon her love,
And indeed killed him, which so won her husband
He slew this right discoverer in his fury,
Who, being my mistress, I was moved in heart
To take some pains with him, and h'as paid me for‘t.
As for the cunning lady, I commend her;
She performed that which never woman tried:
She ran upon two weapons, and so died.
Now you have all, I hope I shall sleep quiet.

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: O, thunder that awakes me e’en from death, And makes me curse my confidence with cold lips, I feel his words in flames about my soul; H’as more than killed me.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Brother!

speech.speaker: ANS.
speech.line: I repent the smile
That I bestowed on destiny! A whore!
Speaks to Body of Wife I fling thee thus from my believing breast With all the strength I have. My rage is great, Although my veins grow beggars. Now I sue
To die far from thee! May we never meet!
Were my soul bid to joy’s eternal banquet, And were assured to find thee there a guest, I‘d sup with torments, and refuse that feast. O thou beguiler of man’s easy trust!
'The serpent’s wisdom is in women’s lust.'

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Is death so long a-coming to mankind It must be met half ways? 'Las, the full time Is to eternity but a minute. Was that so long to stay? O cruel speed!
There’s few men pay their debts before their day.
If they be ready at their time, ‘tis wellâ€”
And but a few that are so. What strange haste
Was made among these people! My heart weeps for‘t.
Go, bear these bodies to a place more comely.

Brother, I came for thy advice, but I Find thee so ill a counsellor to thyself That I repent my pains, and depart sighing. The body of my love is still at court; I am not well to think on’t. The poor spirit Was with me once again about it, troth; And I can put off no more for shame, Though I desire to have it haunt me still And never to give over, ‘tis so pleasing. I must to court: I've plighted my faith to’t; 'T'as opened me the way to the revenge. Tyrant, I’ll run thee on a dangerous shelf, Though I be forced to fly this land myself.

scene.scenepersonae: (Tyrant, Lady Luscinda, First Soldier, Second Soldier, Third Soldier, Fourth Soldier, Govianus)

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: In vain my spirit wrestles with my blood;
Affection will be mistress here on earth.
The house is hers, the soul is but a tenant. I ha’ tasked myself but with the abstinence Of one poor hour, yet cannot conquer that. I cannot keep from sight of her so long.
I starve mine eye too much. Go, bring her forth,
As we have caused her body to be decked
In all the glorious riches of our palace.
Our mind has felt a famine for the time;
All comfort has been dear and scarce with us.
The times are altered since.
Strike on, sweet harmony!
A braver world comes toward us.

They bring the body in a chair, dressed up in black velvet, which sets out the paleness of the hands and face, and a fair chain of pearl 'cross her breast, and the crucifix above it. He stands silent awhile, letting the music play, beckoning the soldiers that bring her in to make obeisance to her, and he himself makes a low honour to the body and kisses the hand.
A song within, in voices Song

O, what is beauty, that’s so much adored? A flattering glass that cozens her beholders, One night of death makes it look pale and horrid: The dainty preserved flesh, how soon it moulders! To love it living, it bewitcheth many, But after life is seldom heard of any.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: By this hand, mere idolatry! I make curtsy To my damnation. I have learnt so much, Though I could never know the meaning yet Of all my Latin prayers, nor ne’er sought for‘t.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: How pleasing art thou to us even in death! I love thee yet, above all women living, And shall do sev'n year hence. I can see nothing to be mended in thee But the too constant paleness of thy cheek. I‘d give the kingdom but to purchase there The breadth of a red rose in natural colour, And think it the best bargain that ever king made yet. But fate’s my hindrance, And I must only rest content with art; And that I’ll have in spite on’t. Is he come, sir?

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Who, my lord?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Dull! The fellow that we sent
For a court schoomaster, a picture drawer, A lady’s forenoon tutor. Is he come, sir?

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Not yet returned, my lord.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: The fool belike
Makes his choice carefully, for so we charged him,
To fit our close deeds with some private hand.
It is no shame for thee, most silent mistress,
To stand in need of art, when youth
And all thy warm friends has forsook thee.
Women alive are glad to seek her friendship
To make up the fair number of their graces, Or else the reckoning would fall short sometimes, And servants would look out for better wages.

scene.stagedir: Enter Third Soldier with Govianus, disguised.

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: He’s come, my lord.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Depart then.
Is that he?

speech.speaker: 3. SOLD.
speech.line: The privatest I could get, my lord.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: O heaven, marry patience to my spirit! Give me a sober fury, I beseech thee, A rage that may not overcharge my blood And do myself most hurt! 'Tis strange to me To see thee here at court, and gone from hence. Didst thou make haste to leave the world for this? And kept in the worst comer? O, who dares play with destiny but he That wears security so thick upon him The thought of death and hell cannot pierce through?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: 'Twas circumspectly carried.
Leave us; go.
Be nearer, sir; thou'rt much commended to us.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: It is the hand, my lord, commends the workman.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Thou speak’st both modesty and truth in that.
We need that art that thou art master of.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: My king is master both of that and me.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Look on yon face and tell me what it wants.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Which, that, sir?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: That! What wants it?

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Troth, my lord
Some thousand years’ sleep and a marble pillow.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: What’s that?
Observe it still! All the best arts Hath the most fools and drunkards to their masters
Thy apprehension has too gross a film
To be employed at court. What colour wants she?

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: By my troth, all, sir; I see none she has,
Nor none she cares for.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: I am overmatched here.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: A lower chamber with less noise were kindlier For her, poor woman, whatsoe'er she was.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: But how if we be pleased to have it thus,
And thee well hired to do what we command?
Is not your work for money?

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Yes, my lord;
I would not trust at court and I could choose.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Let but thy art hide death upon her face, That now looks fearfully on us, and but strive
To give our eye delight in that pale part
Which draws so many pities from these springs,
And thy reward for‘t shall outlast thy end,
And reach to thy friend’s fortunes, and his friend.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Say you so, my lord? I’ll work out my heart then But I’ll show art enough.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: About it, then!
I never wished so seriously for health After long sickness.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: A religious trembling shakes me by the hand, And bids me put by such unhallowed business, But revenge calls for‘t, and it must go forward.
'Tis time the spirit of my love took rest; Poor soul, ‘tis weary, much abused and toiled.

scene.stagedir: Govianus paints the face of the body

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Could I now send for one to renew heat Within her bosom, that were a fine workman;
I should but too much love him. But alas,
'Tis as unpossible for living fire
To take hold there as for dead ashes to burn back again
Into those hard tough bodies whence they fell.
Life is removed from her now, as the warmth
Of the bright sun from us when it makes winter
And kills with unkind coldness. So is‘t yonder; An everlasting frost hangs now upon her. And in such a season men will force A heat into their bloods with exercise
In spite of extreme weather, so shall we
By art force beauty on yon lady’s face; Though death sit frowning on’t a storm of hail To beat it off, our pleasure shall prevail.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Hast done so soon?

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: That’s as your grace
Gives approbation.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O, she lives again!
She'll presently speak to me. Keep her up; I’ll have her swoon no more; there’s treachery in‘t. Does she not feel warm to thee?

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Very little, sir.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: The heat wants cherishing then. Our arms and lips
Shall labour life into her. Wake, sweet mistress!
speech.stagedir: He kisses the lips of the body.
speech.line: 'Tis I that call thee at the door of life. Ha! I talk so long to death, I’m sick myself. Methinks an evil scent still follows me.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Maybe ‘tis nothing but the colour, sir, That I laid on.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Is that so strong?

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Yes, faith, sir,
'Twas the best poison I could get for money.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Govianus!

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: O, thou sacrilegious villain!
Thou thief of rest, robber of monuments! Cannot the body after funeral
Sleep in the grave for thee? Must it be raised
Only to please the wickedness of thine eye?
Does all things end with death, and not thy lust?
Hast thou devised a new way to damnation,
More dreadful than the soul of any sin
Did ever pass yet between earth and hell?
Dost strive to be particularly plagued Above all ghosts beside? Is thy pride such
Thou scorn’st a partner in thy torments too?

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: What fury gave thee boldness to attempt
This deed? For which I’ll doom thee with a death
Beyond the Frenchmen’s tortures.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: I smile at thee.
Draw all the death that ever mankind suffered Unto one head, to help thine own invention, And make my end as rare as this thy sin,
And full as fearful to the eyes of women!
My spirit shall fly singing to his lodging
In midst of that rough weather. Doom me, Tyrant.
Had I feared death, I‘d never appeared noble
To seal this act upon me, which e’en honours me
Unto my mistress’ spirit. It loves me for‘t.
I told my heart ‘twould prove destruction to’t.
Who, hearing ‘twas for her, charged me to do‘t.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Thy glories shall be shortened! Who’s within there?
speech.stagedir: Enter the Ghost, in the same form as the Lady is dressed in the chair.
speech.line: I called not thee, thou enemy to firmness, Mortality’s earthquake!

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Welcome to mine eyes
As is the day spring from the morning’s womb Unto that wretch whose nights are tedious!
As liberty to captives, health to labourers,
And life still to old people, never weary on’t;
So welcome art thou to me. The deed’s done,
Thou queen of spirits; he has his end upon him.
Thy body shall return to rise again,
For thy abuser falls, and has no power
To vex thee farther now.

speech.speaker: LADY.
speech.line: My truest love!
Life ever honoured here, and blessed above.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: O, if there be a hell for flesh and spirit, 'Us built within this bosom.
My lords, treason!

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Now death, I’m for thee. Welcome!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Your king’s poisoned!

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: The King of heaven be praised for‘t!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Lay hold on himâ€”
On Govianus!

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: E’en with the best loves
And truest hearts that ever subjects owed.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: How’s that? I charge you all, lay hands on him.

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: Look you, my lord, your will shall be obeyed:
Here comes another; we'll have his hand too.

speech.speaker: HELV.
speech.line: You shall have both mine, if that work go forward, Beside my voice and knee.

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: Helvetius!
Then my destruction was confirmed amongst ‘em;
Premeditation wrought it. O my torments!

speech.speaker: ALL
speech.line: Live Govianus long our virtuous king!

speech.speaker: TYR.
speech.line: That thunder strikes me dead.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: I cannot better
Reward my joys than with astonished silence, For all the wealth of words is not of power
To make up thanks for you, my honoured lords!
I’m like a man plucked up from many waters, That never looked for help, and am here placed Upon this cheerful mountain, where prosperity
Shoots forth her richest beam.

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: Long-injured lord,
The tyranny of his actions grew so weighty,
His life so viciousâ€”

speech.speaker: HELV.
speech.line: To which this is witness-
Monster in sin!â€”this, the disquieted body Of my too resolute child in honour’s war.

speech.speaker: MEMP.
speech.line: â€”That he became as hateful to our mindsâ€”

speech.speaker: HELV.
speech.line: As death’s unwelcome to a house of riches,
Or what can more express it.

speech.speaker: GOV.
speech.line: Well, he’s gone;
And all the kingdom’s evils perish with him! And since the body of that virtuous lady Is taken from her rest, in memory
Of her admired mistress, ‘tis our will
It receive honour dead, as it took part
With us in all afflictions when it lived.
Here place her in this throne, crown her our queen,
The first and last that ever we make ours,
Her constancy strikes so much firmness in us.
That honour done, let her be solemnly borne Unto the house of peace from whence she came, As Queen of Silence.
The Spirit enters again and stays to go out with the body, as if it were attending it
O welcome, blessed spirit! Thou need’st not mistrust me; I have a care
As jealous as thine own. We'll see it done,
And not believe report; our zeal is such
We cannot reverence chastity too much.
Lead on! I would those ladies that fill honour’s rooms
Might all be borne so honest to their tombs.
Recorders or other solemn music plays them out.
